title: Sound
subject: Physics
learning_objectives: Understand how sound is produced and travels
Learn about characteristics of sound waves
Explore speed of sound in different media
Understand echoes and applications of sound

sections.title: Production of Sound
sections.content:
**Sound is produced by vibrating objects.**

**Examples:**
• Vocal cords vibrate to produce voice
• Guitar strings vibrate to produce music
• Drum membrane vibrates when struck
• Tuning fork prongs vibrate

**Important:** Sound needs a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. It cannot travel through vacuum.

In space, astronauts cannot hear each other directly because there is no air!

sections.title: Sound Waves
sections.content:
Sound travels as **longitudinal waves** - particles vibrate back and forth in the same direction as the wave travels.

**Compressions:** Regions where particles are close together (high pressure)

**Rarefactions:** Regions where particles are far apart (low pressure)

**Characteristics of sound waves:**
• Wavelength (λ): Distance between two consecutive compressions or rarefactions
• Frequency (f): Number of oscillations per second (measured in Hertz, Hz)
• Amplitude: Maximum displacement of particles (determines loudness)

sections.title: Speed of Sound
sections.content:
**Formula:** v = f × λ (Speed = Frequency × Wavelength)

**Speed of sound in different media:**
• Air (at 20°C): 343 m/s
• Water: 1498 m/s
• Steel: 5960 m/s

**General rule:** Sound travels fastest in solids, slower in liquids, and slowest in gases.

**Factors affecting speed:**
• Temperature (increases with temperature in gases)
• Density and elasticity of medium

sections.title: Characteristics of Sound
sections.content:
**1. Loudness:**
• How loud or soft a sound is
• Depends on amplitude
• Measured in decibels (dB)
• Normal conversation: ~60 dB

**2. Pitch:**
• How high or low a sound is
• Depends on frequency
• High frequency → High pitch (whistle)
• Low frequency → Low pitch (bass drum)

**3. Quality/Timbre:**
• What makes sounds unique
• Why a guitar sounds different from a violin

sections.title: Echo and Applications
sections.content:
**Echo:** Reflection of sound from a surface back to the listener.

For echo to be heard distinctly:
• Minimum distance to reflecting surface: 17.2 m
• Time gap required: 0.1 second

**Applications of sound:**
• **SONAR:** Used by ships to detect underwater objects
• **Ultrasound:** Medical imaging, cleaning
• **Stethoscope:** Doctors listen to heart sounds
• **Megaphone:** Amplifies sound

**Ultrasound:** Sound with frequency > 20,000 Hz (above human hearing range)

key_points: Sound is produced by vibrating objects and needs a medium to travel
Sound travels as longitudinal waves with compressions and rarefactions
Speed of sound: Solids > Liquids > Gases
Loudness depends on amplitude; Pitch depends on frequency

quiz_questions.question: Sound waves are:
quiz_questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal waves where particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave travel.

quiz_questions.question: In which medium does sound travel fastest?
quiz_questions.explanation: Sound travels fastest in solids like steel because particles are closely packed.

quiz_questions.question: What determines the pitch of a sound?
quiz_questions.explanation: Pitch is determined by frequency - higher frequency means higher pitch.

quiz_questions.question: Why can't sound travel through space?
quiz_questions.explanation: Sound needs a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. Space is a vacuum with no particles.
